translated: The discussion of what is not fully understood

original: Rūpaṁ na aniccaṁ na saṅkhataṁ na paṭiccasamuppannaṁ na khayadhammaṁ na vayadhammaṁ na virāgadhammaṁ na nirodhadhammaṁ na vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: rūpam na aniccam na saṅkhatam na paṭicca samuppannam na khaya dhammam na vaya dhammam na virāga dhammam na nirodha dhammam na vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: “Is form not impermanent, not conditioned, not dependently arisen, not subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: nanu rūpaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: nanu rūpam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhamman ti
translated: “But is form impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci rūpaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ …pe…🔽vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  rūpam aniccam saṅkhatam pe  vipariṇāma dhamma no ca vata re vattabbe

translated: “Then it is not right to say that form is not fully understood.”

original: Āmantā.🔽Nanu yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: āmantā  nanu yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā

translated: “Has it not been said by the Blessed One that whatever is impermanent is suffering?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā
translated: “Yes.”🔽“But is it not the case that form is impermanent?”🔽“Yes.”

original: “rūpaṁ aniccaṁ”, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: rūpam anicca no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Then it is not right to say that suffering itself is fully understood.”

analyzed: viññāṇam  cakkha āyatanam pe  dhamma āyatanam  cakkhu dhātu  dhammadhātu
translated: “ The mental-data sense sphere …🔽“ The eye element …🔽“ The mental-data element …
“ The final-knower faculty is not fully developed”?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: nanu aññātāvindriyam aniccam saṅkhatam pe vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: “Then is it not the case that the final-knower faculty is impermanent, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci aññātāvindriyaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci aññātāvindriyam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhamma no ca vata re vattabbe

translated: “Then it is not right to say that the final-knower faculty is not fully developed.”

original: Āmantā.🔽Nanu yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: āmantā  nanu yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā

translated: “Has it not been said by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened: ‘Whatever is impermanent is suffering’?”
“Yes.”🔽“Then is the final-knower faculty not impermanent?”🔽“Yes.”

original: Hañci yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—🔽“aññātāvindriyaṁ aniccaṁ”, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā  aññātāvindriyam anicca no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “‘Whatever is impermanent is suffering’ was said by the Blessed One.
‘The faculty of final knowledge is impermanent.’ But it would not be proper to say that it is only suffering that is fully developed.”
The Discussion of What is Not Fully Developed is finished.🔽The twenty-third sub-chapter on “The One Who is Not Fully Developed” is finished.

original: Tassuddānaṁ🔽Ekādhippāyena methuno dhammo paṭisevitabbo, arahantānaṁ vaṇṇena amanussā methunaṁ🔽dhammaṁ paṭisevanti, bodhisatto issariyakāmakārikāhetu vinipātaṁ gacchati, gabbhaseyyaṁ🔽okkamati, dukkarakārikaṁ akāsi, aparantapaṁ akāsi, aññaṁ satthāraṁ uddisi, atthi🔽na rāgo rāgapatirūpako, atthi na doso dosapatirūpako, atthi na moho mohapatirūpako
analyzed: tassa uddāna  eka adhippāyena methunaḥ dhammo paṭisevitabbaḥ arahantānam vaṇṇena amanussāḥ methuna  dhammam paṭisevanti bodhisatto issariya kāma kārikā hetu vinipātam gacchati gabbhaseyya  okkamati dukkara kārikam akāsi aparantapam akāsi aññam satthāram uddisi atthi  na rāgaḥ rāga patirūpakaḥ atthi na dosaḥ dosa patirūpakaḥ atthi na mohaḥ moha patirūpakaḥ

original: atthi na kileso kilesapatirūpako, rūpaṁ aparinipphannaṁ aññātāvindriyaṁ aparinipphannanti.
analyzed: atthi na kilesaḥ kilesa patirūpakaḥ rūpam a parinipphannam aññātāvindriyam a parinipphannanti
translated: “With one intention, one should practice the way of sensual desire; non-human beings practice the way of sensual desire with the praise of arahants; the Bodhisatta goes to the lower realms because of the practice of sensual desire for sovereignty; one enters into the state of being in the womb; one does what is difficult to do; one does what is painful to do; one points out another teacher; there is no passion that is like passion; there is no hatred that is like hatred; there is no delusion that is like delusion; there is no defilement that is like a defilement; form is not fully developed; the faculty of final knowledge is not fully developed.”
The crushing of the words of others,
and the suttas as the basis, collected together;
The illumination at the time of the Teacher,
the section on the grounds for disputes.
The section on the grounds for disputes is finished.
